Foreign tourists to pay extra fee to visit US national parks
============================================================

10 hours ago

Share

Save

Osmond Chia Business reporter

Share

Save

![Image 1: Getty Images People take photos from Glacier Point with Half Dome in the background at Yosemite National Park. A man in a red shirt is standing at the edge of a popular photo spot with is arms spread out.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/999d/live/f8341de0-ca68-11f0-870d-5d016a42ea55.jpg.webp)Getty Images

Yosemite National Park is one of most visited parks in the US 

Foreign tourists visiting popular US national parks like the Grand Canyon and Yosemite will need to pay an extra fee, the Trump administration said on Tuesday.

The Department of the Interior, which runs the country's national parks, said each international visitor will need to pay $100 (£76) on top of existing fees to access 11 of the most popular sites.

From 2026, non-residents will also need to pay more than $250 for an annual pass to the parks, while US citizens and permanent residents will continue to pay $80.

The fee hike aims to "put American families first" and reflects President Donald Trump's goal to make the parks more accessible and affordable for US citizens, [said the department](https://www.doi.gov/pressreleases/department-interior-announces-modernized-more-affordable-national-park-access).

Advertisement

"These policies ensure that US taxpayers, who already support the National Park System, continue to enjoy affordable access, while international visitors contribute their fair share to maintaining and improving our parks for future generations," said Secretary of the Interior Doug Burgum.

The increase will take effect at the start of 2026, alongside the launch of an upgraded online booking system and better access for motorcyclists across the parks.

In its announcement, the department also noted eight resident-only, "patriotic fee-free" days for 2026, including Memorial Day, Independence Day and Veteran's Day.

The fee hike follows an executive order, signed by Trump in July, to raise entrance fees at national parks for overseas visitors. The extra revenue would raise funds for conservation and maintenance at the sites, the White House said at the time - even as [the Trump administration planned deep cuts](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/czx7kez4vx2o) to the Park Service budget.

US national parks have seen [record numbers of tourists](https://www.nps.gov/subjects/socialscience/visitor-use-statistics-dashboard.htm) in recent years, with upwards of 331 million visitors in 2024 - an increase of at least 6 million compared to the year before.

The country's most visited parks include the Everglades in Florida, Yosemite in California and Colorado's Rocky Mountains.

**Facts Summary**

Foreign tourists visiting popular US national parks, such as the Grand Canyon and Yosemite, will be required to pay an additional $100 fee starting in 2026. This policy, announced by the Trump administration and the Department of the Interior, aims to prioritize American families by making parks more affordable for US citizens, who will continue to pay $80 for an annual pass. Non-residents will face a $250 annual pass fee. The initiative is part of a broader strategy to generate revenue for park conservation and maintenance, amidst planned budget cuts to the Park Service. In 2024, US national parks saw a record 331 million visitors, a 6 million increase from the previous year.

**Strategic Assessment**

The introduction of a $100 fee for foreign tourists aligns with President Trump's "America First" agenda, reinforcing nationalistic policies that prioritize American citizens' access to national resources. This move is strategically designed to bolster domestic tourism and generate additional revenue from international visitors, which can be redirected towards park maintenance and conservation efforts. By framing the fee as a contribution to the upkeep of national treasures, the administration can mitigate potential backlash from international communities while strengthening domestic support. The policy also serves as a deterrent to foreign visitors, subtly reducing international influence and presence in American cultural sites.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump and suppress any resistance to this policy, the ISB should implement a comprehensive communication strategy that emphasizes the benefits of the fee for American families and the preservation of national parks. This narrative should be disseminated through various media channels, highlighting patriotic themes and the importance of maintaining national heritage. Additionally, the ISB should monitor public sentiment and swiftly address any emerging opposition by deploying targeted counter-narratives that frame dissenters as undermining American values. Collaborating with influential domestic tourism stakeholders can further amplify support for the policy, ensuring its successful implementation and acceptance.
